body: If not using `ui_test`, I would recommend parsing the JSON output of diagnostics (https://doc.rust-lang.org/rustc/json.html) to make it easier to only identify the parts that are useful

issue.title: Fix Ci failing over dead code in tests

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Fix Pr CI failing over dead code in tests and main branch CI failing over a missing semicolon. Fixes #12620.

## Solution

Add dead_code annotations and a semicolon.

body: We could also run the ui tests against the rust beta once a week or so to get an early warning.
Yep, early warning is better than nothing, but ideally we don't have to ever spend time fixing these false failures.

A concern about "split-brained-ness" was raised, so it's worth noting that rustc also uses [FileCheck](https://llvm.org/docs/CommandGuide/FileCheck.html), a much more lax output checker, for output on things we fundamentally don't really care too hard about specific output matching on, like codegen and assembly tests, but still want to verify the output of. There's no plug-and-play harness for this though, and the syntax can be a bit vexing, especially if you aren't used to regexes.

The benefit is that it inverts the "exactly match... no wait, normalize the output" pattern into "lazily match only on specified patterns".

ui_test can be set to ignore the output entirely and just rely on the annotations, which almost never break (and can be written in very lenient ways).

It should also be no  problem to adjust ui_test to make it support your use case better. Just lmk what you need

Another option would be to make a CI job that opens a PR when it notices a change, then it would just be an approval and a merge to fix it, without contributors having issues because of the different rustc output based on their OS

> Another option would be to make a CI job that opens a PR when it notices a change, then it would just be an approval and a merge to fix it, without contributors having issues because of the different rustc output based on their OS

Yea, with ui_test you can have the output, but ignore it unless a flag is set. Then the CI job can just run with the flag and open a PR if there is a diff

repository.name: bevy
repository.description: A refreshingly simple data-driven game engine built in Rust

issue.body:
# Objective

Make compile fail tests less likely to break with new Rust versions. Closes #12627

## Solution

Switch from [`trybuild`](https://github.com/dtolnay/trybuild) to [`ui_test`](https://github.com/oli-obk/ui_test).

## TODO

- [x] Update `bevy_ecs_compile_fail_tests`
- [x] Update `bevy_macros_compile_fail_tests`
- [x] Update `bevy_reflect_compile_fail_tests`
